captions.zh: 谢谢邀请我来。

captions.zh: 我想从我们之前聊过的一个概念开始，这个我以前从没听说过，但我觉得对大家来说会很有帮助。就是你提到的，从产品作为静态物品到产品像有机体的转变。能不能说说这是什么意思，以及大家需要了解什么？
captions.en: I want to start with something that we were chatting about before this that I've never heard about as a concept that I think is going to be really helpful for people to think about, which is this concept you have that we're moving from product as artifact to product as organism. Talk about what that means and what people need to understand here.

captions.zh:
这真是个有趣的转变，尤其是在过去一年左右。当我加入微软时，正好是 OpenAI 和大型基础模型兴起的时候，紧接着就出现了一波专有和开放前沿的模型，推动了前沿的发展。这些模型变得更高效，然后我们开始看到它们在各个领域的专业化。最近，这些模型甚至可以进行工具调用、功能调用，还能采取行动。我觉得这让新型产品有了成功的机会。

突然之间，产品不再只是我们发布的静态物品了。不是简单地想出个点子，解决个问题，发布出去，稍微改进一下，然后搞个仪表盘。现在，整个关键指标变成了产品团队的"新陈代谢"能力，能否吸收数据，消化奖励模型，并创造出一些结果。因为这些模型现在非常有效，你希望能针对某些结果进行调优，比如价格、性能或质量。

这挺让人兴奋的，因为这些产品就像活的有机体，随着更多的互动而变得更好。在很多方面，我觉得这就是每个公司新的知识产权，这是一种完全不同的产品构建方式，甚至让我们重新思考那些会思考、会成长的产品，真是挺激动人心的。
captions.en: It's a. It's been a pretty interesting shift, especially over the last year or so, because when I got to Microsoft it was kind of right after OpenAI and the large foundation models happen and then immediately after there was this explosion of models Proprietary open frontier models that were pushing the frontier curve. And so they were both more efficient. And then we started to see domain level expertise and a bunch of them. And then, you know, even more recently, models now can, you know, tool call and they can function call and they can take action. And I think that's just giving way to a new type of products that are starting to see some success. And so all of a sudden products aren't just like these static artifacts that we start to ship. It's not just like, hey, come up with an idea or an insight, go solve a problem, ship it into the world, maybe make it a little bit better, and then have a dashboard. All of a sudden the, the whole KPI is what is the, the metabolism of a product team to be able to ingest data and then digest the rewards model and then create some sort of outcome. Because these models are so effective at this point, you want to start to tune them to certain types of outcomes, whether it's price or performance or quality. And so it's pretty exciting because all of a sudden these are these living organisms that just get better with the more interactions that happen. And in many ways I think this is the new IP of every single company and it's a completely different way to build product and to even think about, you know, products that think and live and learn, which is kind of exciting.

captions.zh: 听你这么说，我想到之前请来的 Cursor 的 CEO Michael Turrell，他提到他们的一个大模式是通过用户使用 Cursor 时的数据，比如选择哪些建议、接受哪些、不接受哪些。这是不是你说的意思？就是公司从用户使用产品中收集到的专有数据？还是说还有其他更深的东西？
captions.en: So when I hear this, what I'm thinking about is when I had Michael Turrell on the podcast the Cursor CEO, he talked a lot about how their big mode is the data that they capture from people using cursor, selecting, accepting certain suggestions, not accepting other suggestions. Is that what you're talking about here? Just like the proprietary data that companies gather from people using their product? Or is there something beyond that even?

captions.zh: 我觉得后训练之所以兴起，是因为这些模型本身实在太强大了。今年，Nathan Lambert 做了一项研究，他发现一旦模型参数达到300亿，继续投入大量资金和算力去训练和预运行，就不太划算了，反而可以在循环中进行优化。所以，我觉得用自己的数据来优化是最好的方法。当然，你也可以合成数据，但需要设计奖励机制，推出并认真做AB测试，找到最适合的场景。这样就能产生数据供你学习。我还没见过哪种产品只靠一个循环来运作的，通常都是多条线并行，就像组装线一样，持续输出。
captions.en: I think why we're seeing like the rise of post training happen is just that the, the models themselves like are so powerful. As of this year, Nathan Lambert did this study that I thought was pretty interesting of all the top leaderboards and it showed that, you know, once a model hits 30 billion parameters, the capex to actually train a model and put, you know, billions of tokens into kind of pre run kind of doesn't economically make sense and you can kind of start to optimize on the loop. And so yeah, in many ways I think you can, I think using your own data is the best way to do that. But you can synthetically generate data. You have to come up with a rewards design, you have to actually roll it out, you have to ab test it rigorously you have to find the job to be done or the use case that it makes the most sense for. And then, yes, like that generates data that you can learn from. I haven't ever seen it be one loop for any sort of product. I think it's multiple tracks running in parallel that are kind of like assembly lines, if you will, and kind of producing that.

captions.zh: 所以，你说的产品像有机体的这个观点，是只针对模型公司吗？还是说，对SaaS企业和工具公司也适用呢？
captions.en: And so is this kind of thesis that we're moving towards product as organism, is this, this basically for model companies or is this also true for, I don't know, SaaS businesses and tools and.

captions.zh: 用户工具是什么样的呢？我觉得软件作为一种基础正在改变，其中的一个关键就是模型和软件组件本身。可以说，我认为未来的所有软件产品都会是以模型为主导的产品。
captions.en: User tools look like? I think that software as a primitive is changing and kind of the artifact inside of it is a model alongside the software components itself. And so in many ways I think that, you know, software products will all be model forward products, if you will.

captions.zh: 这让我想到之前请来的 Nick Turley，他是 ChatGPT 的负责人。录音前我们聊到，我问他 GPT5 出来后，ChatGPT 变化有多大？他说，其实没变，还是那个产品。模型告诉我们 ChatGPT 产品要怎么做。这让我想到，为什么 GPT5 不自己构建用户界面呢？就像你用它时，它自己进化。这其实就是它在 Canvas 等应用中的表现。但这也让我想到，当你说产品像有机体时，产品的用户体验可以根据使用情况自动变化，不需要产品团队做什么。
captions.en: This reminds me why I just had Nick Turley on the podcast who we were talking about before we started recording head of ChatGPT. And I was asking just like, how much has ChatGPT changed with GPT5 coming out? And he's just like, it's the same thing, they're the same product. It's just like the model tells us what to do in the product of ChatGPT. And it makes me think about something else of just like you would think, why can't just GPT5 build its own user interface? Just like as you use it, it just evolved. It's sort of what it's doing with Canvas and all these things. But that's another way I think about when you talk about this idea of product as organism is the product the UX can shift based on how you're using it and evolve automatically without having product teams have to do anything.

captions.zh: 我完全相信未来会是这样的，我的体验和你的会不一样。这其实就是个性化的进步，以后可以实时做到。我觉得这会是个很有趣的世界。而且对agent来说，或者对高级用户、新用户来说，体验也会不同。
captions.en: I 100% believe that's where the world is going and that my experience should look and feel different than yours. I mean, that's kind of been the advent and personalization, but now you can do it on the fly in the future. So I think that'll be a pretty fun world. I also think it will look different for agents and it will look different for kind of power users and new users and all of those things too.

captions.zh: 我想稍微放大一点问你个问题。你和很多公司合作，他们在你的平台上，还有其他平台上开发AI产品。我想有些公司做得特别好，发展很快，有些则比较挣扎。你发现那些成功打造出特别优秀AI产品的公司，有哪些共同的模式呢？而那些不太成功的又是怎么样的呢？
captions.en: Let me kind of zoom out a little bit and ask you this question. You work with a bunch of companies that are building AI products on your platform, other platforms. I imagine some just do an awesome job and are killing it, some are struggling. What do you find are kind of common patterns across the companies that do really well and have a lot of success building really successful AI products and ones that Don't.

captions.zh:
嗯，所以我觉得有些东西更多是适用于整个组织本身，还有一些是适用于那些在构建AI产品的人。总体来说，我看到成功公司的一个模式正在显现。首先，他们拥抱AI，让所有人都能熟练使用AI。我觉得大家都在日常工作中使用一些助手或AI工具，所以没人害怕AI，反而知道它能提升技能和任务的上限，同时降低难度。

第二步，他们开始思考，如何将AI应用到现有流程中，让它变得更好。比如客户支持，或者将欺诈处理时间从15天缩短到10天。这个过程就是梳理流程、应用AI、观察影响，然后感受到利润和内在的好处。

第三步就是，好的，现在你看到影响了，大家都在用了，怎么用它推动增长呢？比如提升客户体验，提高客户生命周期价值或留存率。也可能是共同创造新的概念或类别，或者从嵌入式agent到具身agent，能够承担更多任务。

我觉得公司失败的地方在于，他们为了AI而做AI，同时启动很多项目，却没有一个蓝图去理解它是如何运作的，也没有把它当作真正的投资来对待，所以没有设置好测量、观察和评估的机制。企业面临的困难在于技术不断变化。去年有7万个企业级AI工具上线，很难知道该用哪个工具达到什么效果。所以你需要押注一个平台或应用服务器类的层，方便你替换工具，而不是依赖某一项技术或工具。因为整个行业会变，你得为未来变化做好准备，而不是停留在现状。

在企业层面，我看到的就是这样。我觉得那些开发者本身也在发生根本性的变化。每次技术进步都会带来一系列角色的变化，比如从大型机到个人电脑、从服务器到云和移动，出现了SEO专家、CDN、增长黑客、用户体验研究等等。现在我们看到的是多才多艺的开发者崛起，全栈开发者迎来了复兴。一个普通组织可能需要10个步骤才能推出一个产品，可能需要安全审查、规格制定、用户研究等等，涉及五六个功能部门，有六七个层级。突然之间，有500个不同的接触点要去协调才能推出一个产品。而每周有500个新模型或技术出现，这显然不够。因此，我非常相信全栈开发者的概念。你可以在一些新兴的AI公司看到这种趋势，甚至一些有50年历史的企业也开始这样运作。我认为这能带来速度和效率，让你更快地吸收和处理信息。
captions.en: Yeah. So I think there's things that are kind of more broadly applying to the organization themselves and then there's things that are applying to the people who are building the, the AI products too. So more broadly I think there's, there's a pattern that's starting to emerge for successful companies. Like one is they are embracing AI and everybody becomes AI fluent. So I think everybody's using some sort of co pilot or some sort of AI in their day to day workflows like job one. So everyone's not afraid of it, understands how it can raise the ceiling and, and kind of lower, lower the floor for like all sorts of skills and tasks. Number two, from there they start to say, okay, how can I take a process that already exists and apply AI to making it better? That might be something like customer support or taking fraud down from 15 days to kind of cure to 10 days. And like going through that entire loop of mapping out the process, applying AI to it, seeing some sort of impact and then feeling the P and L or the kind of intrinsic benefits that, that, that looks like. The third thing then is like okay, great, now that you've seen impact, everybody is using it, how do you actually use it to inflect growth? And that can be something like improving the customer experience so your LTV or retention improves. It could be co creating a new kind of set of concepts or categories. It could be, you know, going from agents that are embedded to agents that are embodied and then being able to take on, you know, exponential number of tasks. I think that where companies fail is that they're doing AI for AI sake. They have a ton of projects that they're kicking off at the same time without a blueprint to understand how it actually works and what their stack looks like. And they aren't treating it like a real investment and so they don't have the measurement and the observability and the evals all kind of set up. It's going to do that end to end. I think the tricky thing is for enterprises is the technology is changing. There's something like 70,000 enterprise tools like in the AI space launched last year. It's really hard to know which one you should use for what outcome. And so you really need to bet on a platform or some sort of app server type layer that allows you to swap things in and out and not really be beholden to anything, any, any one technology or any one tool. Because the reality is is the whole thing is going to change. Feel like you have to actually build for the slope instead of the snapshot of where you are. So that's, that's kind of what I see at the enterprise level. I think the builders themselves are actually changing pretty fundamentally too. Right. 我觉得每个人都在摸索这个过程。对大公司来说，这比小团队要难多了，因为小团队可以自己跑起来，各有利弊。我们公司之前的产品团队是按学期来计划的，大概每六个月会回顾一下策略，我觉得这挺有价值的。不过，六个月的周期要真正理解前面的变化，确实有点难。所以我们更倾向于看当前的“季节”。这种季节可能因为行业或客户的变化而不太舒服。比如，第一季可能是AI的原型阶段、早期的GPT工作，然后是模型和推理模型的阶段，现在是agent的兴起。这可能持续一年、六个月或三个月。关键是让大家对行业变化、客户问题和成功的标准有共同的理解，这就是我们的北极星指标。

I think like the idea of six months though and really understanding what's changing out in front is truly challenging to kind of have a over baked situation. And so we kind of think about it as, you know, what season are we in. And so a season which is very uncomfortable can be denoted by a set of secular changes that are happening in the industry or that are happening from customers. And so you can think about season one might have been like the prototyping of AI and kind of the early GPT work and then it was all around models and reasoning models and now it's the advent of agents. And so that can last a year, that can last six months, that can last three months. But like grounding everybody on the ethos of what are the secular changes, what are the customer problems we need to solve, what does winning look like? So everybody has that shared sense. What is the North Star metric is something that we do. The second thing that we do is that we have kind of loose quarterly okr. So like, okay, if we believe that what do we need to do next quarter to actually put ourselves on a path to that? I think the other thing is just like we try to leave slack in the system not just for the unplanned but for the slope. 当我刚接手这个角色时，有人形容它像是身处"野兽的肚子"。我之前大部分职业生涯都在围绕机器学习和应用或商业的中心打造产品。让我意外的是，很多学到的东西在于如何打造一个优秀的平台，其实和做一个好产品是一样的。对我来说，往往是那些看不见的工作，或者说不是表面上的东西，才是关键。比如，我第一家公司之一是Porch Group，我是第七号员工。当时我们想帮助人们管理他们的家，所以我们发明了很多功能，比如家庭报告，或者一种管理家的方式，或者房屋风格灵感，你可以看到所有房子的每个房间的地图。最重要的一件事，就是创建一个匹配平台，把600万专业人员和1300种服务类型，还有37000个邮政编码的房主匹配起来，帮助他们更好地管理家。这其实就是一个小步优化的过程，最终提高了线索质量，这让我们公司达到了第一个5亿美元的估值。我们以此为基础，发展出其他垂直服务和软件平台，最终让公司上市。

同样地，在信息传递方面，我学到的最大经验是，WhatsApp之所以成功，不是因为它有贴纸、故事或夜间模式。事实上，它赢得市场时甚至没有这些功能。它成功的原因之一是电话本功能。你知道用WhatsApp可以联系到每一个人，因为你有他们的电话号码。这些是你在使用信息传递时关心的人。还有就是它的可靠性和速度。比如，我可以给在印度的奶奶发信息，确保她能收到。还有就是隐私。当你每天给最关心的四个人发200条信息时，你希望确保没有其他人能看到你的信息。所以端到端加密真的很重要。所以并不是那些上百个功能，而是基础设施和平台。同样的例子还有Instacart。虽然Instacart有很多受欢迎的功能，但最终，它是一个每分钟更新3000次的十亿件商品平台，确保用户从他们喜欢的商店拿到杂货。

所以我希望我早知道这些，因为这样我就能缩短学习曲线，明白平台重要的不是那些功能，而是数据驻留，比如德国的医院可以自信地微调模型，数据不会离开地区。还有可用性和可靠性，确保企业需要的工具选择正确，以及获取知识的正确方式。这就是我们构建的平台，但一开始我没完全意识到这些经验会有这么大的帮助。
captions.en: When I first took the role, it was kind of described as like the belly of the beast. And I had spent most of my career building products at the center of machine learning and applications or businesses. And I think that to my surprise, a lot of the learnings have translated in terms of what makes a great platform, is what makes a great product. And the thing for me is it's often in the invisible work or the not the pixels that actually drives that. So like for example, one of the first companies that I worked at was a company called Porch Group. I was employee seven and we knew we wanted to help people take care of their home. And I think we invented so many features like the home report or like a way to manage your home or like house style inspiration where you could like see all of the, the houses and it's map, map every single room. And the single most important thing that we could have done and did during my time there was create a matching platform that matched the 6 million professionals with the 1300 service types of the 37,000 zip codes and all of the homeowners in North America to actually take care of their, their home. And that was just the game of inches and kind of optimizing that engine in order to create higher quality leads. Essentially that's what got us to the first $500,500,000,000 valuation. That's eventually what we built on to actually have other vertical services and software platforms that IPO the company. Same with messaging. The number one learning that I had was look like WhatsApp didn't win because it had stickers or stories or dark mode. In fact, I don't even think it had all of those things when it won't. It won on a few premises because one was the phone book. Like you knew that when you use WhatsApp you could reach every single person because you had their phone number. And those are the people that you care about when you're using messaging. It was the reliability and how fast it was. Like I could text my grandmother in India and know that she would get my text message all the time. And then it was the privacy. Like when you are sending 200 messages a day to the four people you care about most, you want to make sure no one else can read the messages. And so the end to end encryption really mattered. And so it wasn't the hundreds of features. It was all in kind of the infrastructure and the platform. And same with Instacart. Right. Like, there are so many loved features of Instacart, but at the end of the day, it's a billion Items that updates 3,000 times every single minute to get homeowners their groceries from the store that they love. And so I think, I wish I had known that because I think it would have curtailed my learning curve to say that it's not all the features for the platform that matters. It's the data residency, so the hospital in Germany, that's fine tuning a model can do so in confidence. And the data isn't going to leave the region. It's the availability, it's the reliability. It's making sure you have the right selection of the tools that enterprises need and the right way to retrieve the knowledge. And that's kind of the platform that we've built, but just didn't fully have that picture that those learnings would translate.

summary.zh: 访谈深入探讨了agentic社会对组织架构的影响，以及产品从静态到有机体化的转变。还揭示了成功AI产品公司的共性策略，并讨论了未来代码与用户界面的变化趋势。
summary.en: The interview delves into the impact of agentic society on organizational structures and the transition of products from static to organic entities. It also reveals common strategies of successful AI product companies and discusses future trends in code versus user interfaces.

keyPoints.title: 产品如有机体般成长
highlights: 产品从静态物品转变为有机体，能思考、成长、学习。
这种转变使公司新的IP变得独特。
产品互动越多，就愈显生命力。

keyPoints.title: 成功AI产品的三步策略
highlights: 拥抱AI，让所有人熟练使用。
将AI应用于现有流程提升效率。

keyPoints.title: 从GUI到代码原生接口
highlights: 产品开发需重视组合性而非界面。
代码接口趋势正在取代传统GUI。
文本流更适合连接大型语言模型。

keyPoints.title: agentic社会的颠覆性变化
highlights: 未来组织架构将转向以工作为核心。
边际成本接近零，生产力指数增长。
agent将成为工具和软件的一部分。

keyPoints.title: 后期训练的重要性
highlights: 微调和优化现有模型更具经济性。
强化学习将成为关键的产品技术。
定制化模型体验提升用户价值。
